--Two representatives of the Hopkins Forensic Society, formerly the
Debating Council, will meet two
English students on tour in a debate scheduled for next Tuesday,
October 27th, to open the University debating season, it was recently
announced. The subject to be discussed is "Resolved: That the dole
provides a better solution of the
unemployment problem than does
the charity system."
Hopkins To Uphold Negative
The Hopkins varsity is to uphold
the negative. There will be no decision, in keeping with the Englishmen's request.
The debate will be held in Levering Hall at 4 P. M. Dean Berry,
according to officials of the Forensic Society, has consented to
erve as chairman for the evening.
First Debate Of Schedule
Next Tuesday's debate is the first
of a schedule arranged by the
Forensians. However, a complete
schedule bas not been issued, .although it was said that the next
debate will occur in December or
January.
Accorded official recognition iai.e
last year by the Students Activities
Council, this meeting marks the first
international contest to be held at
Hopkins in recent years. The activity was reorganized prior to its
recognition, in. order to more effeciently control debating.
Debaiting Class Es,tablished
In keeping ~vi th this policy, a
class was established under the
leadership of Clifford P. Lyons,
coach of the organization and an
instructor and student in the English Department. The group of debaters, selected from a large number of candidates number 18. At
present, they are engaged in writing
affirmative and negative briefs on
the dole question.
The men who meet every .Friday evening from 7.00 to 9.00 P.
M., will receive 4 points credit from
the University. It was explained
by Mr. Lyons that practically all of
the students will get a chance to
debate publicly. However, he continued, the actual debating is to be
the outcome of serious and
thorough discussion of current
problems of both political and economic importance. The hurried
manner in which the preparation for
Tuesday's contest is being made, he
said, is only because of the shortness of time.

Oliver asserted that a student's
medical education now begins in
the undergraduate school.
"In the past, Cl:iemistry, Physics
and Mathematics were taught in the
Medical Schools, but with the advent of the new era in science, the
crowded condition of the Medical
Institutions necessitates collegiate
training in these subjects.
Advises Study of Greek
"While a student is in the undergraduate school, it would not be
amiss to study a little Greek and to
become familiar with the French
and German," Dr. Oliver advised,
"for these are important factors in
medical education."
Both Art and Science
Dr. Oliver disclosed the five
characteristics necessary to a physician's success, namely, curiousity,
accuracy, patience, endurance, devotion to the profession, and a deep
interest in people.
Dr. Oliver declared that medicine is both an art and a science,
and that a doctor mnst be interested
n his patients, not only as machines,
but as living human beings.
"The physician who truly loves
his work will be happy even if he
does not gain outstanding fame,"
he said.
